module.p: dìth need, lack, want, deficiency, deficit, shortage, ruin is a (usually) masculine common noun, with genitive form dìthe. [This noun was neuter in Old Gaelic and hence is feminine in some modern dialects.]

Examples with a genitive modifier –
dìth cleachdaidh lack of practice [Watson 2001: 150]
dìth cèille a lack of common sense [Watson 2001: 150] cf. dìth-chèile insanity [Mark 2004: 232]
dìth smachd indiscipline [Mark 2004: 232]
Cha mhòr nach do chuir e bàs mi le dìth bithidh, agus sgiùrs e mi gach làtha le crios leathraich.
He nearly killed me with lack of food, and he lashed me every day with a leather belt. td. 5
Dé bha seo ach am Bàs – dìth cànain, balbhachd.
What was this if not Death – loss of language, muteness td. 54–5
Ann an sùil na h-inntinne chunnaic e a h-aghaidh bhòidheach mus do mharbh hearoan i. Dh’fhairich e fearg a bha dlùthadh ri dìth-cèille. Seo na daoine a mhurt Peigi.
In his mind’s eye he saw her beautiful face before heroin killed her. He fekt an anger which was close to insanity. These were the men who had murdered Peggy. td. 118
Ann an Dùn Èideann anns na naochadan bha barrachd agus barrachd inbhich airson Gàidhlig ionnsachadh agus ged a nochd mòran chlasaichean agus cùrsaichean Gàidhlig airson iarrtasan nan daoine sin a fhreagradh, bha ionnsachadh na Gàidhlig ga bhacadh gu mòr air sgàth dìth shuidheachaidhean far an cluinnear an cànan ga bruidhinn gu nàdarra.
In Edinburgh in the 90s there were more and more people wanting to learn Gaelic and although a lot of Gaelic classes and courses sprang up to respond to the demands of those people, Gaelic learning was largely inhibited because of lack of situations where one could hear the language spoken naturally. td. 85

Or perhaps a specifier –
tha dìth a’ chadail orm I need / lack sleep [Mark 2004: 232]
Bha mo cheann goirt le dìth a’ chadail a dh’aindeoin nan Codeins.
My head hurt with lack of sleep in spite of the Codeines. td. 103
Nach bochd cho beag agus a tha sinn a’ faicinn de leabhraichean ùra Gàidhlig. Tha mi cinnteach gu bheil coire mhór aig dìth an airgid ris an so.
It is a shame how few new Gaelic books we see. I am sure that lack of money is largely to blame for this. td. 280
Chunnaic sinn cuid de na Cuimrich ag éiridh an aghaidh nan Sassunach a chuir glinn aca fo uisge airson tart nan bailtean mora, agus gu dearbh tha a’ cheist so fada nas cudthromaiche ann an Sassuinn do bhrìgh aireamh an t-sluaigh anns na bailtean mora aca, agus dìth nam beanntan àrda a tha againne ann an Alba.
We saw some of the Welsh rising up against the English who flooded their valleys for the thirst of the cities, and certainly this question is far more important in England because of the number of people in their cities, and the lack of the high mountains we have in Scotland. td. 39
Bha a’ chlann dìreach mar dhoilichean, an gnùisean a’ fàs leth-bhàn le dìth na fala.
The children were just like dolls, their faces growing pale with lack of blood. td. 29

cf. bi dìth ... air have need of –
dè tha dìth ort? what do you want? [Robertson & MacDonald 2004: 47]
nuair nach robh dìth airgid orra when they weren’t short of money [Mark 2004: 232]

Negative examples –
Cha robh dìth shearmoinean dùrachdach agus drùiteach oirnn.
We had no shortage of fervent, moving sermons. td. 4
Bha a’ choille pailt, agus cha bhiodh dìth connaidh orra.
The forest was abundant, and they did not lack for fuel. td. 5
Cha robh dìth éisg air duine beag no mór fhads a thigeadh iasg air dubhan.
No one, large or small, was short of fish as long as fish would come on a hook. td. 25

bi a/de dhìth be lacking/missing/wanting/needed –
tha biadh a dhìth food is lacking/in short supply [Watson 2001: 150]
bha feadhainn a dhìth there were some missing [Robertson & MacDonald 2004: 47]
tha luchd-teagaisg a dhìth teachers are needed [Mark 2004: 232]
Chaidh trì uairean a thìde seachad mus do mhothaich duine gu robh Harry Heyford a dhìth.
Three hours had passed before anyone noticed that Harry Heyford was missing. td. 62

bi a/de dhìth air –
dè tha a dhìth oirbh? what do you want/need? what would you like? what are you wanting? [Watson 2001: 150]
tha còta a dhìth orm I need/want a coat [Watson 2001: 150]
tha rudeigin a dhìth orm I want something [Mark 2004: 232]
tha rudeigin a dhìth air it lacks something [Mark 2004: 232]
tha rud eile a dhìth air an aithisg seo this report lacks something else / there is something else lacking in this report [Mark 2004: 232]
mas e sin a bha a dhìth orra if that’s what they wanted [Mark 2004: 232]
dè that a dhìth air? what does he want/lack? [Mark 2004: 232]
feumaidh sinn leabhraichean a chur do na sgoiltean a tha iad a dhìth orra we must send books to the schools that lack them [Mark 2004: 232]
cha robh a dhìth oirnn ach gum faigheamaid cothrom a bhith a’ leughadh we wanted nothing but to get the chance to be reading [Mark 2004: 232]
tha 50sg a dhìth orm [Cox 2017: 320]
chan eil ach £500 a dhìth orm mus fhaigh mi an càr [Cox 2017: 338]
’S e a’ chiad rud a nì sinn càr a cheannach ’s a h-uile càil a tha dhìth òirnn.
The first thing we will do is buy a car and everything we have need of. td. 28–9
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Bhiodh a leòr aige ri dhèanamh an toiseach ag ath-nuadhachadh dreach a’ Chomuinn. Tha móran ri dhèanamh ris a’ Mhòd mus beir e air linn an telebhisean, no eadhon air linn an réidio: [...] tha co-fharpaisean ùra ann an litreachas, ann an ceòl, ann an dràma is ann an ealain a dhìth air a’ Mhòd. Tha cumadh ùr a dhìth air na co-fharpaisean is air na cuirmean-ciùil. [...] Tha cumadh, is dreach, is brìgh ùr a dhìth air leabhraichean, ’s air mìosachan a’ Chomuinn.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] He would have enough to do initially reforming the Society. There is much to do at the Mod before it catches up with ?? the era of television, or even with the era of radio: [...] new competitions in literature, in music, in drama and in art are needed at the Mod. The competitions and the concerts need a new format. [...] The Society’s books and monthly magazines need a new format, design and substance. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’

bi a/de dhìth + GEN with subject as the person –
is fheàrr a bhith a dhìth a’ chinn na a bhith a dhìth an fhasain it’s better to be lacking a head than to be lacking fashion [Mark 2004: 232]
thèid mi an urras nach bi thu a dhìth cobhair I’ll warrant you’ll not lack assistance [Mark 2004: 232]

Also: with subject as the thing –
dè tha dhad dhìth? [Cox 2017: 337, perhaps for What do you want/need?]
rach a (do?) dhìth perish, die off/out, go short, miscarry, go to (rack and) ruin, spoil –

ul.li: cha tèid sinn a dhìth we won’t go short [Watson 2001: 150]
a’ dol a dhìth perishing, dying [Robertson & MacDonald 2004: 47]
chaidh iad uile a dhìth feadh na h-oidhche they all perished during the night [Mark 2004: 232]
tha mòran de na sgeulachdan sin a’ dol a dhìth many of those stories are dying out [Mark 2004: 232]
tha iad a’ leigeil leis na h-àitean aca a dhol a dhìth they are letting their places go to rack and ruin [Mark 2004: 232]
dè that a dhìth air? what does he want/lack? [Mark 2004: 232]
chuireadh sin an cosnadh aca a dhìth ceart gu leòr that would destroy their employment right enough [Mark 2004: 232]

module.p: Note that dìth is not a generic quantity noun (or in fact any kind of quantity expression), since the following kinds of usage are all unacceptable –

ul.li: Cò mheud uisge a tha agad? – Tha dìth (uisge) agam. for How much water do you have? – I have too little.
Dh’òl Raonaid dìth (fìona) for Rachel drank too little (wine)
Cheannaich Seumas dìth de na coin for James bought too few of the dogs

module.p: It seems that the meaning of dìth is not an insufficient quantity of something but rather the state of having an insufficient quantity of something.
cf. cion lack, want, shortage, easbhaidh
